newsitem.title: USA: Cahners Business Confidence Index at 66.6 in Jan.
newsitem.headline: Cahners Business Confidence Index at 66.6 in Jan.

text.p: The Cahners Business Confidence Index (CBCI) rose to 66.6 in January from 66.2 the month before, Cahners Economics said.

"With CBCI just slightly above its 12-month average, the business community seems to be telling us they see calm waters and clear sailing ahead for the early months of 1997," said Cahners economist Kim Kennedy, who prepared the report.

Of the seven CBCI components, the employment index rose most strongly in January, climbing 1.7 points to stand at 66.7. The research and development index turned in the second-best performance, rising to 64.7 from 63.4 the month before.
"January's only significant decline was in new product introductions, which, at this late stage in the business cycle, might be expected," Kennedy said.
Regionally, confidence was strongest in the West, at 68.4. Confidence fell off somewhat in the South, to 65.7 in January from 68.4 in December.
Most survey respondents said 1997 economic conditions will be much like those of 1996.
"Growth will remain in the moderate 2.0- to 2.5-percent range, with both interest rates and inflation remaining subdued," Kennedy said.
